head.title: Cobalt Ferrite Nanoparticles to Form a Catalytic Co–Fe Alloy Carbide Phase for Selective CO2 Hydrogenation to Light Olefins | ACS Catalysis

meta.content: Cobalt Ferrite Nanoparticles to Form a Catalytic Co–Fe Alloy Carbide Phase for Selective CO2 Hydrogenation to Light Olefins

Monodisperse nanoparticles (NPs) of CoFe2O4 were synthesized as efficient catalyst precursors for CO2 hydrogenation to produce high value-added C2–C4 olefin products, which are important building blocks for the chemical industry. The resulting Na-promoted CoFe2O4 catalysts supported on carbon nanotubes (Na–CoFe2O4/CNT) exhibited high CO2 conversion (∼34%) and light olefin selectivity (∼39%), outperforming other reported Fe-based catalysts under similar reaction conditions. Their performance was superior to that of single-metal NP catalysts (Na–Fe3O4/CNT and Na–Co/CNT) and a physically mixed (Na–Fe3O4 + Co)/CNT catalyst. The superior performance of the Na–CoFe2O4/CNT catalyst can be attributed to the facile formation of a unique bimetallic alloy carbide (Fe1–xCox)5C2, which results in higher CO2 conversion and better selectivity toward light olefins in comparison with conventional χ-Fe5C2 active sites derived from Fe-only catalysts and significantly improved heavy hydrocarbon (C2+) formation in comparison with the Co2C sites of Co-only catalysts. The single-source precursor CoFe2O4 exclusively forms a single-phase alloy carbide promoted by the Na promoter, whereas the mixed (Na–Fe3O4 + Co) precursor forms an isolated Co phase with the alloy carbide phase, promoting undesirable CH4 formation. An optimal value of x ≤ 0.2 for (Fe1–xCox)5C2 was predicted using the cluster expansion method and density functional theory, resulting in a stable bimetallic alloy structure.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The steady increase of CO
2
in the atmosphere owing to the excessive use of fossil fuels is seriously threatening the future of humankind by accelerating climate change.
(1−3)
However, catalytic chemistry can turn this harmful greenhouse gas into a renewable source of carbon to provide an alternative feedstock for producing high-value hydrocarbon fuels, chemicals, and polymers as a carbon capture and utilization (CCU) strategy.
(4,5)
Among the proposed CCU options, catalytic CO
2
hydrogenation is attractive because the process is very similar to the well-established CO hydrogenation.
(6−8)
The CO
2
hydrogenation process usually involves two consecutive steps: the reverse water–gas shift (RWGS) and subsequent CO hydrogenation reactions.
(6)
Thus, although a wide variety of transition metals such as Fe, Co, Ni, Mo, and Ru are common CO hydrogenation catalysts, only metals with significant RWGS activity are effective for direct CO
2
hydrogenation.
(9−13)
In CO
2
hydrogenation over Fe-based catalysts, the Fe
3
O
4
phase catalyzes the RWGS reaction, and its reduced form, the Hägg iron carbide (χ-Fe
5
C
2
) phase, provides active sites for CO hydrogenation and chain growth.
(14−19)
The reduction step and subsequent
in situ
carburization during direct CO
2
hydrogenation result in the transformation of the original Fe
3
O
4
phase into various iron carbides.
(14−19)
Depending on the electronic structure and surface properties of the iron carbide species, CO
2
hydrogenation can produce a wide variety of products, including methane, light olefins (C
2
=
–C
4
=
), and heavier (C
5+
) hydrocarbons.
(14−19)
However, the selective synthesis of light olefins as key building blocks in the chemical industry is much more desirable than producing methane of lower value or heavier hydrocarbons.
(20)

To increase the CO
2
conversion and light olefin selectivity, various strategies have been used to control the electronic and structural properties of Fe-based catalysts.
(21−36)
In particular, alkali metals such as Na, K, and Cs act as electronic promoters by donating electrons to metal atoms on the catalyst surface, and dramatically change the catalytic activity, even when present in only tiny amounts (≪1 wt %). These alkali promoters can activate CO
2
and CO by making the surface charge of Fe-based catalysts more negative. This altered surface charge then facilitates the formation of the active iron carbide structure on the surface, thus contributing to increased selectivity for light olefins. Another strategy is to introduce a secondary metal such as Mn, Co, Cu, or Zn to increase the reducibility and number of active sites through the high dispersion of active metals, leading to increased olefin yields.
(26−39)
In particular, the inclusion of Co as the secondary metal to form Co–Fe bimetallic catalysts has attracted much attention as CO hydrogenation over Co catalysts has intrinsically high reaction rates.
(31,32)
Satthawong
et al.
reported that tuning the composition of the Co–Fe bimetallic phase increased the adsorption of CO
2
and H
2
, thus leading to increased CO
2
conversion.
(31)
The incorporation of K promoters in the bimetallic catalysts further increased the yield of light olefins.
(36)
Recently, Gnanamani
et al.
studied CO
2
hydrogenation by adjusting the composition and pretreatment conditions of Co–Fe bimetallic catalysts and showed that pretreatment with CO facilitated the formation of the iron carbide structure responsible for the high selectivity of C
2+
hydrocarbons.
(32)
These studies demonstrated the importance of iron carbides in Fe-based catalysts for direct CO
2
hydrogenation. However, there have been very few in-depth studies of iron carbides because of their metastable properties and difficulties in synthesizing pure phases.
(16,37)
The structures of bimetallic or bimetal alloy carbide catalysts have rarely been analyzed. Furthermore, it is very difficult to identify the structure as it changes rapidly, especially as the supported Fe particles aggregate and deposit carbon on the surface during the high-temperature reaction.
(38−40)
In addition, water produced during direct CO
2
hydrogenation results in further changes in the catalyst surface and is also a major factor in lowering the reaction yields.

Recent advances in colloidal synthetic chemistry provide a unique opportunity to prepare various nanoparticles (NPs) with controlled size, shape, and composition.
(41−43)
Supported catalysts prepared using conventional methods, such as incipient wetness impregnation and deposition precipitation, provide a broad size distribution of metal NPs and uncontrolled interparticle spacing on the support. The structural nonuniformity of these conventionally prepared catalysts makes the relationship between their catalytic activity and structural features ambiguous. Previous studies confirmed that even a small amount of Co changes the catalytic active sites in Fe-based catalysts, thus altering the catalytic performance for CO
2
hydrogenation.
(38−40)
Therefore, if the Co–Fe bimetallic catalyst has a well-defined crystalline nanostructure, the structural and electronic properties of the catalyst could be tailored further to improve the catalytic activity and selectivity.

In this study, we synthesized monodisperse Fe
3
O
4
and CoFe
2
O
4
NPs with a size of 10–20 nm by the thermal decomposition of metal–oleate complexes, which were produced by mixing FeCl
3
, CoCl
2
, and Na–oleate.
(44,45)
The prepared NPs were then supported on carbon nanotubes (CNTs). To study the role of the alkali metal promoter, we controlled the content of Na by adjusting the amount of Na–oleate complex added during the synthesis of the NPs. The Na and Co promoters played decisive roles in controlling the reaction rates and product selectivity of catalytic CO
2
hydrogenation over these reduced CoFe
2
O
4
NP/CNT catalysts. The Na promoter also facilitated the formation of a catalytic (Fe
1–
x
Co
x
)
5
C
2
alloy carbide phase during the reaction. To estimate a plausible configuration for the new (Fe
1–
x
Co
x
)
5
C
2
phase, we used
ab initio
cluster expansion (CE) as a state-of-the-art computational technique.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
To prepare the Fe–oleate complex, 10 mmol of FeCl
3
·6H
2
O (≥98%, Sigma-Aldrich) and 30 mmol of Na–oleate (≥97%, Tokyo Chemical Industry) were combined in a solvent mixture composed of 15 mL of distilled water, 20 mL of ethanol, and 35 mL of
n
-hexane at 60 °C for 5 h. After cooling, the solution was poured into a dropping funnel to separate the upper organic layer containing the Fe–oleate complex from the water layer containing NaCl. The organic layer was further washed with deionized (DI) water to eliminate any remaining Na. After evaporating
n
-hexane, the waxy Fe–oleate complex was obtained. When 3.3 mmol of CoCl
2
·6H
2
O (98%, Alfa Aesar), 6.6 mmol of FeCl
3
·6H
2
O, and 26.4 mmol of Na–oleate were used, Co–Fe–oleate was obtained in a 1:2 ratio of Co–Fe. Depending on the extent of washing with DI water, the concentration of Na in the metal–oleate varied. The Na content in the NPs was further adjusted as desired by adding Na–oleate during the NP synthesis.

Spinel ferrite NPs were synthesized by the thermal decomposition of a metal–oleate complex.
(44,45)
Here, 10 mmol of the as-prepared metal–oleate complex (
i.e.
, Fe–oleate or Co–Fe–oleate) was dissolved in 100 mL of 1-octadecene (90%, Sigma-Aldrich) in a three-neck round-bottom flask (250 mL). For the preparation of Na-promoted NPs, 0.61 g of Na–oleate (2 mmol) was added to the mixture. The three-neck round-bottom flask was then connected to a Schlenk line, and the reaction mixture was heated to 80 °C and evacuated for 30 min to remove water and air. After the degassing process, the temperature was increased to 280 °C at a rate of 2.22 °C·min
–1
under an air-tight Ar atmosphere. After the temperature reached 280 °C, the reaction temperature was increased rapidly to 320 °C for burst nucleation, at which time the initial clear solution became turbid and deep black in color. After refluxing for 30 min, the solution was cooled to room temperature, and the resulting precipitated NPs were centrifuged (6000 rpm) and washed with excess acetone (repeated three times) to remove unreacted precursors and excess oleic acid.

Cobalt NPs were synthesized by the hot injection method.
(46)
First, 130 mg of oleic acid and 15 mL of
o
-dichlorobenzene were added to an inert flask, and then the solution was heated to 168 °C. A separate solution containing 512 mg of Co
2
(CO)
8
(90%, Sigma-Aldrich) in 3 mL of
o
-dichlorobenzene was then rapidly injected into the oleic acid solution. Upon injection, the color of the solution immediately turned black. After maintaining the reaction at the same temperature for 20 min, a black precipitate was collected after washing with 10 mL of
o
-dichlorobenzene and 10 mL of 2-propanol followed by centrifugation (6000 rpm).

To support the NPs on the CNTs, 0.9 g of CNT (Hanwha Nanotech) was sonicated in 30 mL of 1-octadecene for 30 min, and then 0.1 g of NPs was added.
(47,48)
This mixture was then heated to 100 °C and degassed for 15 min. Under an Ar atmosphere, the temperature was increased further at a rate of 10 °C·min
–1
up to 200 °C and then maintained at this temperature for 30 min. The resulting supported NP/CNT catalysts were washed with acetone and
n
-hexane four times. To evaluate the effect of the support on the NP catalysts, Al
2
O
3
(Sasol Puralox SBa-200) and TiO
2
(Degussa P25) were also used as control supports, which were loaded with CoFe
2
O
4
NPs using the same method as used for the CNT support.

Catalytic CO
2
hydrogenation was performed in a stainless steel fixed-bed reactor with an inner diameter of 1/2 in.
(26,27)
Each catalyst (0.22 g) was loaded and pre-reduced in pure H
2
(50 sccm flow) at 400 °C for 3 h. After reduction, the reactor was cooled to 340 °C, and the reactant gases (H
2
/CO
2
/N
2
= 9:3:1) were fed into the reactor at 10 bar and a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 3600 mL·h
–1
·g
cat
–1
. A small amount of N
2
was introduced as an internal standard for gas chromatography (GC) analysis. The gaseous products from the reactor were analyzed using online GC (Agilent Technologies 7890A). N
2
, CO, and CO
2
were analyzed using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD; Carboxen 1000 column), whereas hydrocarbons from C
1
to C
6
were analyzed using the same GC with a flame ionization detector (alumina sulfate PLOT capillary column). The liquid products were collected using a cold trap (0 °C), and analyzed using off-line GC and GC–mass spectrometry (Agilent 7890B, MS 5977B MSD). The representative GC spectra of the gas and liquid products are provided in the
Supporting Information
(Figures S1 and S2). The catalytic performance was evaluated from the continuous reactivity maintained for at least 24 h on stream. The conversion of CO
2
(
X
CO
2
) and the selectivity (
S
) of the products were calculated using the following equations.
(1)
(2)
(3)
(4)
(5)

Transmission electron microscopy (TEM; FEI Tecnai G2 F20 X-Twin) and high-resolution TEM (HR-TEM) operated at 200 kV were used to evaluate the size, shape, and composition of NP catalysts with high-angle annular dark field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM; JEOL JEM-2100F) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping. The crystal structures of the as-synthesized and spent NP catalysts were identified using X-ray diffraction (XRD; Rigaku Ultima III) with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154178 nm).
In situ
powder XRD was also performed using a SmartLab diffractometer (Rigaku) with a D/teX Ultra 250 detector under various gas flows. The catalyst was placed in a black quartz cuvette and then reduced at 600 °C at a heating rate of 25 °C·min
–1
under a flow of pure H
2
(10 sccm) for 4 h. After H
2
treatment, CO was introduced to the reduced catalyst for carburization at 340 °C for 16 h. Both normal and
in situ
powder XRD patterns were obtained using a Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154178 nm) source at 45 kV and 200 mA. The scan range was 10–80° with a scan rate of 4°·min
–1
. The content of metal (Fe, Co, and Na) in the catalysts was analyzed using inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP–OES; Varian 700-ES). The catalyst (40 mg) was completely dissolved in HCl (10 mL) and diluted in DI water for ICP–OES measurements.

X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) measurements were performed at the 7D beamline of the Pohang Accelerator Laboratory, South Korea (3.0 GeV, 400 mA). The synchrotron radiation was monochromated using a Si(111) double-crystal monochromator to eliminate high-order harmonics. The spectrum for the Fe K-edge signal (
E
0
= 7112 eV) was obtained in the transmission mode and that of the Co K-edge signal (
E
0
= 7709 eV) in the fluorescence mode. To minimize the contamination of high harmonics, the incident beam was detuned by 30%. He-filled and N
2
-filled IC SPEC ionization chambers were used to monitor the Fe and Co K-edge signals, respectively. The X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectra of the Fe and Co K-edge regions were obtained in the transmission mode. The background removal and normalization of the Fe and Co K-edge XAS and XANES spectra were performed using the ATHENA module in the IFEFFIT software program. Fe
5
C
2
and Co
2
C were prepared following the reported procedures for use as reference samples.
(49,50)
Other reference samples (Fe
3
O
4
, Co
3
O
4
, and CoO) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (99.99%); metal Co and Fe foils were also used. The linear combination fitting (LCF) method was used to determine the relative ratio of various Fe phases in the spent Fe-based NP catalysts in the 7100–7250 eV region of XANES. In addition, Fe
3
O
4
, FeO, α-Fe, and χ-Fe
5
C
2
were used as reference Fe-based compounds.

Temperature-programmed reduction with H
2
(H
2
-TPR) was performed using a BELCAT II system (Bel Co.). First, 50 mg of the catalyst was purged at room temperature for 30 min with He (50 sccm), then heated to 200 °C, and held at this temperature for 2 h. After cooling to 35 °C, 10% H
2
in He (50 sccm) was introduced and stabilized for 1.5 h. The hydrogen concentration was monitored with TCD at a constant heating rate of 10°·min
–1
between 35 and 600 °C. Temperature-programmed desorption with CO (CO-TPD) was also conducted using BELCAT II in the same manner as H
2
-TPR, with 10% CO in He (30 sccm) and heating up to 900 °C at 10 °C·min
–1
.

div.h3:
2.4. Configuration of (Fe
1–
x
Co
x
)
5
C
2
Using the Computational CE Method
div.div:
The feasibility of Co substitution in the χ-Fe
5
C
2
crystal structure to form (Fe
1–
x
Co
x
)
5
C
2
was evaluated using the CE method, as implemented in the open-source Python package CELL.
(51)
The configuration of the ground state of (Fe
1–
x
Co
x
)
5
C
2
was explored by changing the concentration of Co substituting for Fe. Detailed procedures of the CE for finding the ground-state configuration of alloy structures are provided elsewhere.
(51)
First, the electronic energy of the random structure of the (Fe
1–
x
Co
x
)
5
C
2
alloy was calculated in the range of 0.05 ≤
x
≤ 0.4 using density functional theory (DFT). To generate a CE model based on this energy, the maximum number of points for the entire cluster was set to four, with the maximum radius of 5.0 Å. The root-mean-square error of the trained model was 0.016 eV relative to the DFT energy. Then, the CE model was used to calculate the energy of the new structure created by Metropolis sampling using the Boltzmann distribution. The structure with the lowest energy according to this sampling was recalculated using DFT to estimate the ground-state structure and its energy.

Electronic structure calculations were performed using DFT on a set of plane waves implemented in the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package.
(52,53)
Exchange–correlation interactions were described using the revised Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof
(54)
functional within a generalized gradient approximation. The convergence criterion for geometric optimization was a maximum force of 0.01 eV/Å for an atom. The
k
-point sampling of the 8 × 8 × 8 Monkhorst–Pack mesh grid was used for optimization. The bulk χ-Fe
5
C
2
structure (space group
C
2/
c
) was optimized using Fe
20
C
8
unit cells according to a previous study.
(55)
During the CE procedure, the Co-substituted structure was optimized with a fixed cell volume derived from the initial bulk optimization. The second calculation of the lowest energy structure was performed without any geometrical constraints, which allowed the comparison of the change in the cell volume after Co substitution. For a simple comparison of the energy change because of the Co substitution, the following reaction was assumed to occur

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.h3: 3.1. Preparation and Characterization of Ferrite NP Catalysts
div.div:
Magnetite (Fe
3
O
4
) and cobalt ferrite (CoFe
2
O
4
) NPs with a spinel structure were prepared by the thermal decomposition of metal–oleate precursors.
(44,45)
The decomposition of Fe–oleate and Co–Fe–oleate complexes in 1-octadecene started to produce small clusters by nucleation at 320 °C. Then, NPs grew to average diameters of 13.4 and 10.6 nm for Fe
3
O
4
and CoFe
2
O
4
, respectively, after 30 min of the synthesis reaction. For comparison, Co NPs were also synthesized
via
the hot injection method, in which Co
2
(CO)
8
in dichlorobenzene was injected into a dichlorobenzene solution containing oleic acid at 168 °C.
(46)
The resulting ε-Co NPs had an average diameter of 5.9 nm. Through burst nucleation and controlled growth, monodisperse NPs were generated in the colloidal solution and then deposited on the CNT support by mixing NPs with CNTs in 1-octadecene at 200 °C.
(47,48)
Thus, we prepared CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT, Fe
3
O
4
/CNT, and Co/CNT catalysts. For comparison, a (Fe
3
O
4
+ Co)/CNT catalyst was also prepared by depositing a physical mixture of Fe
3
O
4
and Co NPs on CNTs.

The overall synthesis steps of NP/CNT catalysts are illustrated in
Scheme 1
. The TEM images of the as-synthesized NPs and the corresponding NP catalysts supported on the CNTs confirmed that the NPs were well dispersed over the CNT surfaces (
Figures S3 and S4
). The amount of Na present in the final catalyst was controlled by the extent of washing during the preparation of the metal–oleate complex and the quantity of Na–oleate added to synthesize ferrite NPs. Although the size of the CoFe
2
O
4
NPs increased when Na was added (
Figure S3
), the crystalline spinel structure did not change in either CoFe
2
O
4
or Fe
3
O
4
NPs, as confirmed by XRD (
Figure S5
). The chemical compositions of Co, Fe, and Na in the catalysts determined using ICP–OES are listed in
Table S1
.

div.div:
Catalytic CO

Figure

and
Table S2

O

, CoFe

, Co, and mixed Fe

2+

Figure

–1
·s
–1
) and Fe

/CNT (0.4 μmol

·g
Fe
–1
·s
–1
), respectively (
Figure
1
b). The obtained FTY
=
of the Na–CoFe
2
O

/CNT catalyst reported herein is comparable to the catalysts reported under harsh reaction conditions and is twice that of other reported catalysts under similar reaction conditions (see
Table S4
). In addition, our catalysts are comparable to or better than other Co–Fe bimetallic catalysts, even under the relatively mild reaction conditions (low temperature and pressure) used here. As discussed later, this effect originates from the single-source precursor of spinel CoFe
2
O
4
NPs, in which Co and Fe are atomically mixed, in conjunction with the promoting effect of the Na promoter.

The amount of Na in the CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT catalyst was further controlled to verify the promoting effect of Na (0–0.32 wt %;
Figure S6
). As shown in
Figure S7
, the initial CO
2
conversion of 25.2% in the Na-free CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT catalyst increased to
ca.
35% when the Na content increased to 0.07 wt % and remained at the same level for Na contents of 0.16, 0.22, and 0.32 wt % (
Tables S1 and S2
). However,
S
C
2
=
−C
4
=
increased threefold from 12.8% for Na-free CoFe
2
O

/CNT to 39% for Na–CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT catalysts, with Na contents of 0.22 and 0.32 wt %, respectively. Alkali metals such as Na and K are well known to promote the formation of iron carbides as active species in Fe-based catalysts, resulting in high
S
C
2
=
−C
4
=
and
S
C
5+
,
(20−25)
which is consistent with our observation that Na–CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT catalysts had much higher
S
C

=
−C
4
=
values than the corresponding Na-free catalysts. In addition, the Na–CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT catalyst exhibited excellent durability, without the degradation of its reactivity under more stringent catalytic reaction conditions (340 °C, 10 bar) for more than 72 h (
Figure S8
).

The Anderson–Schulz–Flory distribution and chain growth probability (α) were obtained from the straight portion of hydrocarbon distribution during CO
2
hydrogenation. The obtained α was 0.64 and 0.70 for Na–CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT and Na–Fe
3
O
4
/CNT catalysts, respectively (
Figure S9
). The Na–Fe
3
O
4
/CNT catalyst exhibited higher selectivity toward C
5+
products but lower selectivity toward light olefins in comparison with Na–CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT. The promoted formation of the alloy carbide of Na–CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT derived from CO during the RWGS reaction was responsible for the high FTY
=
, which was not fully achieved by the mixed Na–Fe
3
O
4
+ Co/CNT catalyst. The newly formed alloy carbide of Na–CoFe
2
O
4

5
C
2

To obtain an in-depth understanding of the catalytic performance and the nature of the active sites, the spent NP catalysts were comprehensively analyzed. Usually, Fe-based catalysts for CO
2
hydrogenation contain Fe
3
O
4
as the active phase for RWGS, whereas under the reaction conditions, other phases such as metallic iron (α-Fe), iron oxides (α-Fe
2
O
3
), and iron carbides (Fe
5
C
2
) coexist.
(15−17)
Although the role of each phase is still controversial, it is generally accepted that the Hägg iron carbide (χ-Fe
5
C
2
) is the active phase responsible for high CO
2
conversions and chain growth to olefins and heavy hydrocarbons.
(14−16)
Many studies have also confirmed that the formation of χ-Fe
5
C
2
is promoted by alkali and transition-metal promoters. Because the spent catalysts after CO
2
hydrogenation are completely different from the original NP catalysts, we characterized the NP catalysts before and after the reaction to further study the structural changes in the catalytically relevant environment using
in situ
techniques.

The as-synthesized CoFe
2
O
4
and Fe
3
O
4
possess a typical spinel structure, regardless of the amount of Na present (
Figure S5
). The Co NPs of the mixed (Na–Fe
3
O
4
+ Co)/CNT cannot be identified with XRD because of the overlapping XRD patterns of Co and Fe.
Figure
2
a,b shows the XRD patterns of the spent catalysts with and without the Na promoter after CO
2
hydrogenation for 24 h. The XRD pattern of the Na-free spent catalyst shows peaks attributed to the metallic Fe or bimetallic FeCo phase with a high-intensity peak for Fe
3
O
4
. The most obvious difference in the Na-promoted catalysts is the prevalent formation of the χ-Fe
5
C
2
phase during CO
2
hydrogenation, as indicated by the characteristic XRD peaks at 39.4, 40.8, 43.4, and 44.2° (
Figure
2
b). Interestingly, the spent Na–CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT and Na–Fe
3
O
4
+ Co/CNT had different crystalline structures. In the spent Na–CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT, most of the ferrite structure was transformed to χ-Fe
5
C
2
, and the remaining spinel peak at 35.8° was very small. However, the spent (Na–Fe
3
O
4
+ Co)/CNT showed a strong Fe
3
O
4
peak. The effect of the amount of Na on the phase of Na–CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT was investigated to monitor the formation of the χ-Fe
5
C
2
phase (
Figure S6
). As the amount of Na increased from 0 to 0.32 wt %, the intensity of the bimetallic FeCo alloy peak at 45° decreased, whereas that of the Fe
5
C
2
peaks around 43° increased. These results clearly demonstrate that the high CO
2
conversion and high
S
C
2
=
−C
4
=
v of the Na–CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT catalyst originate from the preferential formation of the active χ-Fe
5
C
2
phase assisted by the Na promoter (
Figure S7
).

div.p: Figure 2. (a,b) XRD of the spent Fe-based NP catalysts. (c) Fe K-edge and (d) Co K-edge XANES profiles of the spent Na-promoted ferrite NP catalysts. All NP catalysts were supported on CNT.

div.div:
Because of the difficulty in characterizing the Co species with XRD, XANES analysis was performed, which is a highly sensitive and element-specific technique. Thus, XANES can identify the local electronic structures of metals, oxides, and carbide phases.
Figure
2
c,d shows the Fe and Co K-edge XANES profiles of the spent Na-promoted catalysts. The Fe K-edge spectrum of the spent Na–CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT is very similar to the line shape of the χ-Fe
5
C
2
reference, which is distinguished from those of the spent (Na–Fe
3
O
4
+ Co)/CNT and Na–Fe
3
O
4
/CNT catalysts. This indicates that the CoFe
2
O
4
structure is predominantly transformed into the χ-Fe
5
C
2
phase during the reaction (
Figure
2
c). To quantify different phases, LCF of Fe XANES was performed, which revealed that the spent Na–CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT consisted mostly of χ-Fe
5
C
2
, whereas the spent Na–Fe
3
O
4
/CNT and (Na–Fe
3
O
4
+ Co)/CNT contained less carbide and fewer metallic phases (
Figures S10 and S11a,b
). When the amount of Na was controlled in the catalyst, the degree of χ-Fe
5
C
2
formation varied systematically, consistent with the XRD results. Thus, the atomically mixed Fe and Co atoms in spinel CoFe
2
O
4
NPs as a single-source precursor more effectively formed the active χ-Fe
5
C
2
phase, assisted by the Na promoter.

In the Co K-edge XANES profile shown in
Figure
2
d, the spent (Na–Fe
3
O
4
+ Co)/CNT shows a higher white line intensity and lower pre-edge intensity than the spent Na–CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT catalyst. The line shape of (Na–Fe
3
O
4
+ Co)/CNT is similar to that of the CoO reference, whereas that of Na–CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT resembles that of Co
2
C.
(56)
However, Na–CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT shows a much stronger pre-edge and a weaker white line than the physically mixed catalyst, indicating that Co formed a more strongly reduced phase, such as a carbide, in this sample. However, Co in spinel CoFe
2
O
4
NPs does not form isolated Co
2
C but instead forms an alloy Hägg carbide structure with Fe, (Fe
1–
x
Co
x
)
5
C
2
, in the presence of Na during CO
2
hydrogenation. When the amount of Na increased (0–0.3 wt %) in CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT, the fraction of the carbide phase also increased (
Figure S11c,d
). These results demonstrate that the presence of the Na promoter plays a crucial role in the formation of the carbide phases of both Fe and Co, and the promoting effect was much greater when the single-source precursor CoFe
2
O
4
was used instead of mixed Fe
3
O
4
+ Co.

The spent Na-promoted catalysts obtained after CO
2
hydrogenation for 24 h were further characterized by HR-TEM and HAADF-STEM with EDS elemental mapping (
Figure
3
). The overall morphology of the spent catalysts shown in the HR-TEM images is a
[email protected]
nanostructure with a crystalline core. The fast Fourier transform (FFT) of the HR-TEM images (insets in
Figure
3
a–c) show ordered diffraction spots of χ-Fe
5
C
2
(510) with a lattice spacing of 2.05 Å, which is in good agreement with the XRD results. The FFT and lattice
d
-spacing values exhibit (Fe
1–
x
Co
x
)
5
C
2
(510) and (11–2) phases for Na–CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT (
Figure
3
a) and the Fe
5
C
2
(−202) phase for Na–Fe
3
O
4
+ Co/CNT (
Figure
3
c). The Na–Fe
3
O
4
/CNT sample exhibited both Fe
5
C
2
(510) and Fe
3
O
4
(111) phases (
Figure
3
b), indicating mixed phases consistent with the XRD results. The crystalline χ-Fe
5
C
2
core was covered with an amorphous shell consisting of iron oxycarbides (
Figure
3
a–c).
(37)
In contrast, the χ-Fe
5
C
2
phase was barely observed for the Na-free spent catalysts (
Figure S12
). HAADF-STEM and the corresponding elemental maps of the spent Na-promoted ferrite catalysts show a uniform distribution of Fe and Co in Fe
5
C
2
NPs (
Figure
3
d–f), revealing that Fe and Co were well mixed in the spent Na–CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT without the segregation of Co or Fe (
Figures
3
d,
S13a
). However, the physically mixed (Na–Fe
3
O
4
+ Co)/CNT catalyst contained segregated Co NPs, with diameters of more than 20 nm, produced during the reaction (
Figures
3
f,
S13b
). The EDS line scans of the STEM image in
Figure S14
show the same information more clearly.

Figure 3. (a–c) HR-TEM and (d–f) HAADF-STEM images with the corresponding EDS elemental maps of the spent Na-promoted ferrite catalysts (insets: FFT patterns extracted from HR-TEM images): (a,d) Na–CoFe

O

/CNT, (b,e) Na–Fe

div.div:
As an additional evidence, we obtained Co K-edge
k
2
-weighted Fourier-transformed extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra for the spent CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT and Na–Fe
3
O
4
+ Co/CNT catalysts. The spent CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT exhibited a distinct Co–C scattering peak at ∼1.5 Å, corresponding to Co
2
C rather than Co or CoO, indicating that Co was uniformly distributed in Fe
5
C
2
to form Co–C bonds (
Figure S15
). However, the spent Na–Fe
3
O
4
+ Co/CNT predominantly exhibited Co–O (1.4–1.8 Å) and Co–Co (2.0–2.2 Å) bonds because Co and Fe were not mixed completely within the same particle. Although the mixed Na–Fe
3
O
4
+ Co/CNT catalyst also formed the Co–Fe alloy carbide during the reaction, the degree of alloy formation was limited because the Co–Fe contact was poor (
Figures
3
f and
S13b
). On the other hand, the Na–CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT catalysts with the atomic-scale Co–Fe contact in the CoFe
2
O
4
structure formed the unique Co–Fe alloy carbide exclusively with a homogeneous distribution of Co and Fe. It was reported that Co can be isomorphically substituted into the lattice of Fe
5
C
2
without considerable lattice distortion in (Fe
1–
x
Co
x
)
5
C
2
NPs.
(57)
Thus, the use of CoFe
2
O
4
NPs as a single-source precursor is important for the formation the pure FeCo alloy carbide, (Fe
1–
x
Co
x
)
5
C
2
, which is the active phase of the Fischer–Tropsch synthesis from CO
2
hydrogenation.

To characterize the reactivity of different catalyst surfaces, CO-TPD and H
2
-TPR were performed (
Figures S16 and S17
). In CO-TPD, the spent Na–CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT catalyst had a lower desorption temperature of CO (452 °C) than the spent Na–Fe
3
O
4
/CNT (525 °C), and its peak intensity was higher (
Figure S16
). This indicates that the newly formed carbide surface of the Na–CoFe
2
O
4
catalyst had a smaller binding energy of CO molecules. The spent (Na–Fe
3
O
4
+ Co)/CNT catalyst showed multiple peaks in the CO-TPD spectrum, originating from the individual Fe
3
O
4
and Co NPs. The H
2
-TPR profiles of the three spent catalysts were also completely different (
Figure S17
). Two peaks were identified in the spent (Na–Fe
3
O
4
+ Co)/CNT catalyst owing to the two kinds of NPs, whereas one broad peak was observed for the spent Na–CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT and Na–Fe
3
O
4
/CNT catalysts. The different binding energies of the catalysts indicate the different natures of the active surface species, which result in the observation of different catalytic behaviors.

To follow the formation of the active catalytic phase during pre-reduction and
in situ
carburization by CO generated during the reaction,
in situ
XRD was performed during reduction at 600 °C under H
2
flow for 4 h, followed by carburization in a CO stream at 340 °C for 16 h. Although the XRD system used here could operate above the reaction temperature, the pressures of CO
2
and H
2
were limited to atmospheric pressure, where the RWGS reaction could not occur to generate enough CO for carburization (
Figure S18
). Thus, we conducted carburization of catalysts by supplying CO during
in situ
XRD to observe the change in the catalytic phase.
Figure
4
shows the evolution of the XRD peaks for the three catalysts under the successive reduction and carburization steps. All the three catalysts clearly show metallic peaks such as Co–Fe, Co, and Fe after being reduced by H
2
at 600 °C. These metallic peaks from CoFe
2
O
4
and Fe
3
O
4
were converted to Fe
5
C
2
and Fe
3
O
4
phases as CO was added. The Fe
3
O
4
phase was formed because oxygen generated from CO during the carburization step oxidized the metallic phase. However, as the time under CO increased, most of Fe
3
O
4
was carburized to show the characteristic χ-Fe
5
C
2
(510) peak in XRD (
Figure
4
a,b). However, the (Na–Fe
3
O
4
+ Co)/CNT catalyst did not form a uniform phase. The individual particles such as Co and Fe in (Na–Fe
3
O
4
+ Co)/CNT aggregated to increase the size during carburization, which was confirmed by the strong metallic peaks in XRD (
Figure
4
c).

div.p:
Figure 4.
In situ
XRD patterns of Na-promoted ferrite catalysts supported on CNTs under H
2
reduction at 600 °C, followed by carburization with CO at 340 °C: (a) Na–CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT, (b) Na–Fe
3
O
4
/CNT, and (c) Na–Fe
3
O
4
+ Co/CNT.

div.div:
These
in situ
characterization results indicated the evolution of the CoFe
2
O
4
structure in the Na–CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT catalyst, as schematically presented in
Scheme 2
. During the initial H
2
reduction, CoFe
2
O
4
was converted into the single Co–Fe alloy phase, which was then converted into the bimetallic alloy carbide (Fe
1–
x
Co
x
)
5
C
2
with the Hägg carbide structure during the subsequent CO
2
hydrogenation by CO generated
in situ
. However, in the case of (Na–Fe
3
O
4
+ Co)/CNT, an isolated Co phase is formed in addition to the Co–Fe alloy carbide phase, resulting in high CH
4
selectivity in CO
2
hydrogenation. The high CH
4
selectivity is characteristic of the single-phase Co catalyst. To confirm the reactivity of the single Co phase, we also prepared Co
2
C NPs
via
simple precipitation and carburization of Co
3
O
4
with CO. In CO
2
hydrogenation under the same conditions, the CH
4
selectivity was as high as 83–98%, regardless of Na promotion and precarburization (
Figures S19 and S20
). The formation of the Co
2
C phase was suppressed under an inert CO
2
environment with a high H
2
/CO
2
ratio. It was observed that CO was required to generate the Co
2
C phase in the Co/CNT catalyst. In the absence of CO, the Co
3
O
4
phase of the Na–Co
3
O
4
catalyst converted into metallic Co (see XRD in
Figure S19
). However, as the concentration of CO increased, distinct XRD peaks corresponding to the Co
2
C phase were clearly observed (
Figure S21
). Based on these results, it was concluded that the promoted formation of alloy carbides (Fe
5
C
2
and Co
2
C) in the Na–CoFe
2
O
4
catalyst was facilitated by the consumption of the intermediate CO produced during the RWGS reaction. The intimate contact between the Co and Fe atoms in the Na–CoFe
2
O
4
catalyst produced a distinct alloy carbide structure, which was not achieved fully in the case of the catalysts with separated Co and Fe
3
O
4
.

Scheme 2. Schematic Illustrations Showing the Phase Transformations of As-Prepared Spinel CoFe
2
O
4
NPs (Top Row) or (Fe
3
O
4
+ Co) NPs (Bottom Row) on CNT Supports during the Pre-reduction and Reaction Steps

The role of the active species in the Co-incorporated Fe carbide is still controversial; however, several theoretical and experimental data demonstrate that the oxidation state of Fe in iron carbide can indicate the activity of CO hydrogenation.
(57−63)
Fe has a higher oxidation state when Co is incorporated into the Fe
5
C
2
lattice.
(57)
Additionally, Fe species with a higher oxidation state tends to exhibit lower electronic density and weaker π-back-donation.
(58)
Because the bonding of CO and Fe is mainly because of π-back-donation, the binding strength of Fe–CO decreases and the activity of CO hydrogenation increases, as the oxidation state of Fe increases.
(59)
A previous study reported that the oxidation state of Fe increased when Co was introduced into the lattice of Fe
5
C
2
.
(57)
Increasing the oxidation state of Fe reduces the CO adsorption strength, which was confirmed by the CO-TPD results; as depicted in
Figure S16
, the spent Na–CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT catalyst exhibited a lower desorption temperature of CO (452 °C) than the spent Na–Fe
3
O
4
/CNT (525 °C), indicating that the newly formed bimetallic alloy carbide (Fe
1–
x
Co
x
)
5
C
2
phase of the Na–CoFe
2
O
4
catalyst had a smaller binding energy of CO molecules. Cheng
et al.
reported that the weaker CO bonding strength of Fe
5
C
2
enhanced the activity of CO hydrogenation.
(60)
In this study, the resulting alloy carbide (Fe
1–
x
Co
x
)
5
C
2
phase induced a high conversion during CO
2
hydrogenation by rapid CO adsorption and subsequent dissociation. However, the RWGS reaction did not occur readily on the Co
2
C surface under high-pressure H
2
conditions because the metallic Co phase, instead of Co carbide, produced CH
4
predominantly because of low CO formation. Although the Na–Fe
3
O
4
/CNT catalyst exhibited similar CO
2
conversion in comparison with the Na–CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT catalyst, FTY
=
increased over the Na–CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT catalyst because of the decreased CO selectivity and suppressed chain growth. Thus, the promoted formation of the alloy carbide (Fe
1–
x
Co
x
)
5
C
2
phase derived from CO during the RWGS reaction was responsible for the high FTY
=
, which was not achieved by Na–Fe
3
O
4
/CNT.

Furthermore, the effect of the CNT support was investigated by comparing with Al
2
O
3
and TiO
2
. The CNT-supported catalysts exhibited higher CO
2
conversion, olefin selectivity, and O/P ratio than the catalysts with other supports owing to the unique electronic properties and large surface area of CNTs (
Figure S22a
,
Table S3
). The XRD results depicted in
Figure S22b–d
confirm that only Na–CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT generates the Fe carbide phase, whereas Na–CoFe
2
O
4
/Al
2
O
3
and Na–CoFe
2
O
4
/TiO
2
produce predominantly metallic phases. Thus, the CNT support was crucial for the preparation of highly dispersed NPs and effective carburization of the metal components.

div.h3:
3.4. Predicting Configurations of (Fe
1–
x
Co
x
)
5
C
2
div.div:
It is well known that the structure of the mixed Co and Fe oxide is the spinel CoFe
2
O
4
. However, the structure of its mixed carbide has not yet been reported. This is presumably because of the metastable nature of Fe carbides and their corrugated XRD patterns, which makes it difficult to clearly distinguish the differences in the crystal structure when Co is intercalated or substituted into the Fe carbide structure. When Fe forms mixed carbides, this phenomenon occurs not only with Co but also with other transition metals in the same period, such as Ni, Cu, and Zn. Our experimental observations (
Figures
2
–
4
) clearly indicated the presence of Co in the χ-Fe
5
C
2
structure, where Co was substituted for Fe without significantly changing the crystal structure of χ-Fe
5
C
2
. In this section, we assess the feasibility of Co substitution using a DFT-based CE approach as a function of Co concentration, that is,
x
in the (Fe
1–
x
Co
x
)
5
C
2
structure. The CE approach is designed to locate the ground state of the alloy without using excessive computational resources. For instance, if
x
varies from 0.05 to 0.4 in a Fe
20
C
8
unit structure, the total number of formation energies that must be compared to find the ground-state structure at each concentration is
ca.
264,000. The CE approach used here enables this structure to be located with only 95
ab initio
calculations. The computational details are summarized in
Figures S23, S24
and
Tables S5–S8
.

The change in the relative formation energy (Δ
E
f
) of the (Fe
1–
x
Co
x
)
5
C
2
structure as a function of
x
is shown in
Figure
5
a. As
x
increases, the increase in Δ
E
f
indicates that the carbide structure becomes unstable when Co is replaced by Fe. The increment becomes greater as more Co substitutes for Fe. For example, as
x
increases from 0 to 0.05, Δ
E
f
of the ground-state structure is only 0.03 eV, whereas as
x
increases from 0.15 to 0.2, it becomes 0.11 eV. This suggests that Co substitution can easily occur at low Co concentrations but may be limited to a certain extent. Because Δ
E
f
contains only electronic information, it is difficult to estimate the number of substitutions that occur using only this value. Instead, one can infer the limit of
x
by changing the volume of the unit structure that changes with
x
. After optimizing the unit cell of the ground-state structure (red circles in
Figure
5
a), the volume expansion of Co-substituted Fe carbides was observed (
Figure
5
b). Considering the experimental observations with no noticeable change in the Fe
5
C
2
lattice, the maximum
x
is expected to be 0.2, above which the volume expands even further. Thus, for a stable structure, the alloy carbide (Fe
1–
x
Co
x
)
5
C
2
produced from CoFe
2
O
4
NPs is concluded to contain Co contents of
x
≤ 0.2.

div.p:
Figure 5. Changes in the (a) relative formation energy (Δ
E
f
) and (b) volume of the (Fe
1–
x
Co
x
)
5
C
2
unit structure as a function of Co concentration,
x
. In (a), the open circles denote the
ab initio
energies of the randomly generated structure, whereas the blue and red circles denote the
ab initio
energies of the ground-state structure with unit cells of fixed and flexible volume, respectively. The bars denote the energy calculated using the CE approach with Metropolis sampling. The typical ground-state structures at each Co concentration are shown in (b).

div.div:
Monodisperse NPs of CoFe
2
O
4
, Fe
3
O
4
, and Co were synthesized and deposited on CNTs to study catalytic CO
2
hydrogenation and the roles of Na and Co promoters in Fe-based catalysts. The Na promoter dramatically increased CO
2
conversion and selectivity to C
2
=
–C
4
=
olefins and C
5+
hydrocarbons, while suppressing the formation of undesirable CH
4
and light paraffins. The Na–Fe
3
O
4
/CNT catalyst showed high selectivity to heavy hydrocarbons (C
2+
) with minimum CH
4
formation. The Na–Co/CNT catalyst showed higher CO
2
conversions but produced mostly CH
4
. When the two catalysts were combined in the form of Na–CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT, both CO
2
conversion and C
2
=
–C
4
=
selectivity increased, whereas the CH
4
fraction increased only slightly, giving the highest FTY values for CO
2
conversion and C
2
=
–C
4
=
production. However, the synergistic effect of Co and Fe was insignificant for the physically mixed (Na–Fe
3
O
4
+ Co)/CNT catalyst.

The excellent performance of Na–CoFe
2
O
4
/CNT was attributed to the formation of the bimetallic alloy carbide (Fe
1–
x
Co
x
)
5
C
2
phase with the Hägg carbide structure, which was the active catalytic site for enhanced activity and preferential chain growth. Various characterization techniques demonstrated that CoFe
2
O
4
was first reduced to metallic FeCo alloy and then transformed exclusively to (Fe
1–
x
Co
x
)
5
C
2
via
carburization by CO generated
in situ
during CO
2
hydrogenation. The carburization reaction was facilitated by the Na promoter. In the case of the physically mixed (Na–Fe
3
O
4
+ Co)/CNT precursor, an isolated Co phase was formed together with the alloy carbide, resulting in high CH
4
selectivity. This justifies our strategy to use monodisperse CoFe
2
O
4
NPs as a single-source precursor to form the single-phase, catalytic alloy carbide phase. The unique alloy carbide phase (Fe
1–
x
Co
x
)
5
C
2
generated from the CoFe
2
O
4
NPs resulted in higher CO
2
conversion and better selectivity toward light olefins than those of conventional χ-Fe
5
C
2
active sites derived from Fe-only catalysts and greatly enhanced C
2+
hydrocarbon formation than the Co
2
C sites of Co-only catalysts. The DFT-based CE approach estimated a Co concentration in the (Fe
1–
x
Co
x
)
5
C
2
structure of less than 0.2 for a stable structure. By combining experimental and theoretical studies, we identified a unique (Fe
1–
x
Co
x
)
5
C
2
structure (
x
≤ 0.2) derived from Na-promoted CoFe
2
O
4
NPs as the single-source precursor. Research on CO
2
hydrogenation using well-defined NPs for producing high value-added chemicals can provide valuable insights into the design of high-performance catalysts, which can contribute to slowing climate change by recycling CO
2
to produce fuels and chemicals.

A review. Fossil fuel depletion, global warming, climate change, and steep hikes in the price of fuels are driving scientists to investigate on com. and environmentally friendly fuels. The process of CO2 conversion to value-added products has been considered as a possible remedy to fulfill the requirements. The present review paper comprehensively discusses two different processes, namely hydrocarbon and methanol synthesis which are extensively used to convert CO2 to value-added products. Reaction mechanisms as well as the effects of catalyst, reactor type and operating conditions on product efficiency enhancement of each process are reviewed. Furthermore a brief overview on the reactor types as the most effective component of the theor. and exptl. reported results on the process improvement is given. All the information is tabulated in order to make the gathered information easily conclusive. Finally, by taking the available information into account the best reactor configuration which is adjustable to reaction mechanism is proposed.

A review. While Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS) technologies are being developed with the focus of capturing and storing CO2 in huge quantities, new methods for the chem. exploitation of carbon dioxide (CCU) are being developed in parallel. The intensified chem. or phys. utilization of CO2 is targeted at generating value from a limited part of the CO2 stream and developing better and more efficient chem. processes with reduced CO2 footprint. Here, we compare the status of the three main lines of CCS technologies with respect to efficiency, energy consumption, and tech. feasibility as well as the implications of CCS on the efficiency and structure of the energy supply chain.

A review. In recent years, Carbon Capture and Storage (Sequestration) (CCS) has been proposed as a potential method to allow the continued use of fossil-fuelled power stations while preventing emissions of CO2 from reaching the atm. Gas, coal (and biomass)-fired power stations can respond to changes in demand more readily than many other sources of electricity prodn., hence the importance of retaining them as an option in the energy mix. Here, we review the leading CO2 capture technologies, available in the short and long term, and their technol. maturity, before discussing CO2 transport and storage. Current pilot plants and demonstrations are highlighted, as is the importance of optimizing the CCS system as a whole. Other topics briefly discussed include the viability of both the capture of CO2 from the air and CO2 reutilization as climate change mitigation strategies. Finally, we discuss the economic and legal aspects of CCS.

Chem. utilization of CO2 to chems. and fuels is very attractive because it can not only alleviate global warming caused by increasing atm. CO2 concn. but also offer a soln. to replace dwindling fossil fuels. Hydrogen is a high-energy material and can be used as the reagent for CO2 transformation. Moreover, when hydrogen originates directly from renewable energy, CO2 hydrogenation can also provide an important approach for dealing with the intermittence of renewable sources by storing energy in chems. and fuels. Therefore, much attention has been paid to CO2 hydrogenation to various value-added hydrocarbons, such as lower olefins, liquefied petroleum gas, gasoline, aroms. and so on. The focus of this perspective article is on the indirect and direct routes for prodn. of hydrocarbons from CO2 hydrogenation and recent developments in catalyst design, catalytic performance and reaction mechanism. In addn., a brief overview on CO2 hydrogenation to methanol is given, which is a crit. process in the indirect route involving conversion of CO2 into methanol and subsequent transformation into hydrocarbons. We also provide an overview of the challenges in and opportunities for future research assocd. with CO2 hydrogenation to value-added hydrocarbons.

A review. The utilization of CO2 for the prodn. of useful chems. using heterogeneous catalysts is one of the ways to reduce the anthropogenic greenhouse gases in the atm. In many cases, the CO2 conversion and products yield are still considered very low and need to be operated at high pressure and temp. The crit. point in CO2 conversion is to activate the CO2 mols. either by adding a co-reactant or by using effective catalysts. This paper presents the current development on the effect of several precursors like metals, metal oxides, ionic liqs., and acid-base loaded on a suitable support in creating magical properties of catalysts on the performance of CO2 conversion. Cu/ZnO-based catalysts, ionic liq.-based catalysts, and metal oxides-based catalysts are reported to be the most effective catalysts in the formation of methanol, cyclic carbonates and di-Me carbonate. This review also focuses on various strategies and developments in altering heterogeneous catalysts, followed by crit. factors of CO2 mol. activation, and the optimization of the catalytic activity or catalysts reusability.

Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis to Olefins: Catalytic Performance and Structure Evolution of Co2C-Based Catalysts under a CO2 Environment
Lin, Tiejun; Gong, Kun; Wang, Caiqi; An, Yunlei; Wang, Xinxing; Qi, Xingzhen; Li, Shenggang; Lu, Yongwu; Zhong, Liangshu; Sun, Yuhan
ACS Catalysis
(

9
(
10
),
9554-9567
CODEN:
ACCACS
; ISSN:
2155-5435
.
(
American Chemical Society
)
Cobalt carbide (Co2C) nanoprisms derived from CoMn composite oxides exhibit promising catalytic performance for Fischer-Tropsch to olefins (FTO) synthesis via H2-lean syngas conversion, but with nearly 45 C% of CO2 selectivity. The work herein was aimed to investigate the effect of CO2 in the feed on the structure-performance relationship of Co2C-based catalysts during a realistic FTO process. An obvious neg. effect of CO2 was obsd. on the catalytic performance, and the presence of CO2 greatly decreased the catalytic activity and olefin formation rate, while it facilitated methane formation. In addn., the product distribution shifted toward light components at increasing CO2 content, and a typical methanation regime with low selectivity to olefins was obsd. for CO2 hydrogenation. A structural characterization suggested that the Na-promoted Co2C nanoprisms remained stable under FTO working conditions, and weak linearly and bridge adsorbed CO mols. were obsd. when the temp. reached 250 °C in a flow of CO-contg. gas. However, the CO2 environment hindered CO adsorption, and the strong CO2 adsorption ability led to decreased CO coverage and a high local H2/CO ratio on the catalyst surface. The as-obtained CO-lean and H-rich surface microenvironment gradually changed the morphol. of Co2C nanostructures from nanoprisms to nanospheres. Some of the Co2C was even transformed into metallic Co. The change of the catalyst structure and the surrounding environment inhibited the adsorption of surface intermediates and the subsequent chain growth. This work provides important insights for further catalyst optimization and suggests that CO2 removal is necessary for recycling the tail gas or using CO2-contg. feedstocks for industrial FTO processes over Co2C-based catalysts.

Discovery of a Ni-Ga catalyst for carbon dioxide reduction to methanol
Studt, Felix; Sharafutdinov, Irek; Abild-Pedersen, Frank; Elkjaer, Christian F.; Hummelshoj, Jens S.; Dahl, Soren; Chorkendorff, Ib; Norskov, Jens K.

The use of methanol as a fuel and chem. feedstock could become very important in the development of a more sustainable society if methanol could be efficiently obtained from the direct redn. of CO2 using solar-generated hydrogen. If hydrogen prodn. is to be decentralized, small-scale CO2 redn. devices are required that operate at low pressures. Here, we report the discovery of a Ni-Ga catalyst that reduces CO2 to methanol at ambient pressure. The catalyst was identified through a descriptor-based anal. of the process and the use of computational methods to identify Ni-Ga intermetallic compds. as stable candidates with good activity. We synthesized and tested a series of catalysts and found that Ni5Ga3 is particularly active and selective. Comparison with conventional Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts revealed the same or better methanol synthesis activity, as well as considerably lower prodn. of CO. We suggest that this is a first step towards the development of small-scale low-pressure devices for CO2 redn. to methanol.

Ruthenium nanoparticles with a core-shell structure formed by a core of metallic ruthenium and a shell of ruthenium carbide have been synthesized by a mild and easy hydrothermal treatment. The dual structure and compn. of the nanoparticles have been detd. by synchrotron XPS, near-edge X-ray absorption fine structure (NEXAFS) anal., and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) imaging. According to depth profile synchrotron XPS and X-ray diffraction (XRD) anal., metallic ruthenium species predominate in the inner layers of the material, ruthenium carbide species being located on the upper surface layers. The ruthenium carbon catalysts presented herein are able to activate both CO2 and H2, exhibiting exceptional high activity for CO2 hydrogenation at low temps. (160-200°) with 100% selectivity to methane, surpassing by far the most active Ru catalysts reported up to now. On the basis of catalytic studies and isotopic 13CO/12CO2/H2 expts., the active sites responsible for this unprecedented activity can be assocd. with surface ruthenium carbide (RuC) species, which enable CO2 activation and transformation to methane via a direct CO2 hydrogenation mechanism. Both the high activity and the absence of CO in the gas effluent confer relevance to these catalysts for the Sabatier reaction, a chem. process with renewed interest for storing surplus renewable energy in the form of methane.

Rising atm. CO2 is expected to have neg. effects on the global environment from its role in climate change and ocean acidification. Utilizing CO2 as a feedstock to make valuable chems. is potentially more desirable than sequestration. A substantial redn. of CO2 levels requires a large-scale CO2 catalytic conversion process, which in turn requires the discovery of low-cost catalysts. Results from the current study demonstrate the feasibility of using the non-precious metal material molybdenum carbide (Mo2C) as an active and selective catalyst for CO2 conversion by H2.

A review. Replacement of part of the fossil fuel consumption by renewable energy, in particular in the chem. industry, is a central strategy for resource and energy efficiency. This perspective will show that CO2 is the key mol. to proceed effectively in this direction. The routes, opportunities and barriers in increasing the share of renewable energy by using CO2 reaction and their impact on the chem. and energy value chains are discussed after introducing the general aspects of this topic evidencing the tight integration between the CO2 use and renewable energy insertion in the value chain of the process industry. The focus of this perspective article is on the catalytic aspects of the chemistries involved, with an anal. of the state-of-the-art, perspectives and targets to be developed. The reactions discussed are the prodn. of short-chain olefins (ethylene, propylene) from CO2, and the conversion of carbon dioxide to syngas, formic acid, methanol and di-Me ether, hydrocarbons via Fischer-Tropsch synthesis and methane. The relevance of availability, cost and environmental footprints of H2 prodn. routes using renewable energies is addressed. The final part discusses the possible scenario for CO2 as an intermediary for the incorporation of renewable energy in the process industry, with a concise road-map for catalysis needs and barriers to reach this goal.

A review. One of the main initiatives for fighting climate change is to use carbon dioxide as a resource instead of waste. In this respect, thermocatalytic carbon dioxide hydrogenation to high-added-value chems. is a promising process. Among the products of this reaction (alcs., alkanes, olefins, or aroms.), light olefins are interesting because they are building blocks for making polymers, as well as other important chems. Olefins are mainly produced from fossil fuel sources, but the increasing demand of plastics boosts the need to develop more sustainable synthetic routes. This review gives a crit. overview of the most recent achievements in direct carbon dioxide hydrogenation to light olefins, which can take place through two competitive routes: the modified Fischer-Tropsch synthesis and methanol-mediated synthesis. Both routes are compared in terms of catalyst development, reaction performance, and reaction mechanisms. Furthermore, practical aspects of the commercialization of this reaction, such as renewable hydrogen prodn. and carbon dioxide capture, compression, and transport, are discussed. It is concluded that, to date, the catalysts used in the carbon dioxide hydrogenation reaction give a wide product distribution, which reduces the specific selectivity to lower olefins. More efforts are needed to reach better control of the C/H surface ratio and interactions within the functionalities of the catalyst, as well as understanding the reaction mechanism and avoiding deactivation. Renewable H2 prodn. and carbon dioxide capture and transport technologies are being developed, although they are currently still too expensive for industrial application.

A review. Iron-based Fischer-Tropsch catalysts, which are applied in the conversion of CO and H2 into longer hydrocarbon chains, are historically amongst the most intensively studied systems in heterogeneous catalysis. Despite this, fundamental understanding of the complex and dynamic chem. of the iron-carbon-oxygen system and its implications for the rapid deactivation of the iron-based catalysts is still a developing field. Fischer-Tropsch catalysis is characterized by its multidisciplinary nature and therefore deals with a wide variety of fundamental chem. and phys. problems. This crit. review will summarize the current state of knowledge of the underlying mechanisms for the activation and eventual deactivation of iron-based Fischer-Tropsch catalysts and suggest systematic approaches for relating chem. identity to performance in next generation iron-based catalyst systems (210 refs.).

The influence of different iron carbides on the activity and selectivity of iron-based Fischer-Tropsch catalysts has been studied. Different iron carbide phases are obtained by the pretreatment of a binary Fe/SiO2 model catalyst (prepd. by copptn. method) to different gas atmospheres (syngas, CO, or H2). The phase structures, compns., and particle sizes of the catalysts are characterized systematically by XRD, XAFS, MES, and TEM. It is found that in the syngas-treated catalyst only χ-Fe5C2 carbide is formed. In the CO-treated catalyst, Fe7C3 and χ-Fe5C2 with a bimodal particle size distribution are formed, while the H2-treated catalyst exhibits the bimodal size distributed ε-Fe2C and χ-Fe5C2 after a Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) reaction. The intrinsic FTS activity is calcd. and assigned to each corresponding iron carbide based on the phase compn. and the particle size. It is identified that Fe7C3 has the highest intrinsic activity (TOF = 4.59 × 10-2 s-1) among the three candidate carbides (ε-Fe2C, Fe7C3, and χ-Fe5C2) in typical medium-temp. Fischer-Tropsch (MTFT) conditions (260-300 °C, 2-3 MPa, and H2/CO = 2). Moreover, FTS over ε-Fe2C leads to the lowest methane selectivity.

The Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) is a feasible pathway to chems. and fuels from underutilized resources like coal, natural gas, biomass, and shale gas, instead of the current petroleum-based prodn. Owing to its high activity and low price, the iron-based catalysts are widely used in FTS, yet catalysts with higher activity and better selectivity should be developed for widespread applications. Herein, we report a unique strategy to synthesize an efficient iron catalyst for FTS by applying a graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) as a sacrificial support. The iron catalyst on g-C3N4 is effectively reduced to a state that is rapidly and selectively converted to highly cryst. and pure Haegg carbide (χ-Fe5C2) phase during the FTS reaction. The obtained catalyst exhibits outstanding CO conversion, and high selectivity for C5+ products, outperforming most of the recently reported carbon-based iron catalysts.

A review. C2 to C4 olefins are traditionally produced from steam cracking of naphtha. The necessity for alternative prodn. routes for these major commodity chems. via non-oil-based processes has driven research in past times during the oil crises. Currently, there is a renewed interest in producing lower olefins from alternative feedstocks such as coal, natural gas, or biomass, in view of high oil prices, environmental regulations, and strategies to gain independence from oil imports. This review describes the major routes for the prodn. of lower olefins from synthesis gas with an emphasis on a direct or single step process, the so-called FTO or Fischer-Tropsch to olefins process. The different catalysts for FTO are outlined and compared, and the key issues and requirements for future developments are highlighted. Iron-based catalysts are prevailing for FTO, and reproducible lower olefin selectivities of 50 wt % of hydrocarbons produced have been realized at CO conversions higher than 70% for 60 to 1000 h on stream. Remarkably the high selectivity to lower olefins has been achieved over a broad range of process conditions (P, T, H2/CO ratio, GHSV). A major challenge for further development and application of FTO catalysts is the suppression of carbon lay-down to enhance catalyst lifetime and to preserve their phys. integrity under demanding reaction conditions.

Although considerable progress has been made in direct synthesis gas (syngas) conversion to light olefins (C2=-C4=) via Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS), the wide product distribution remains a challenge, with a theor. limit of only 58% for C2-C4 hydrocarbons. We present a process that reaches C2=-C4= selectivity as high as 80% and C2-C4 94% at carbon monoxide (CO) conversion of 17%. This is enabled by a bifunctional catalyst affording two types of active sites with complementary properties. The partially reduced oxide surface (ZnCrOx) activates CO and H2, and C-C coupling is subsequently manipulated within the confined acidic pores of zeolites. No obvious deactivation is obsd. within 110 h. Furthermore, this composite catalyst and the process may allow use of coal- and biomass-derived syngas with a low H2/CO ratio.

Direct conversion of CO2 into isoparaffins, ideal clean hydrocarbon fuel components, would be an eco-friendly way of mitigating CO2 emissions and replacing fossil fuels. Herein, a one-step high-yield synthesis is realized of isoparaffins from CO2 hydrogenation, catalyzed by a multifunctional Na-Fe3O4/HMCM-22 catalyst. A selectivity of 82% among hydrocarbons was achieved for C4+ hydrocarbons, of which isoparaffins could account for 74%, while CO selectivity was as low as 17% at a CO2 conversion of 26%. The high yield to isoparaffins was derived owing to well matching of three tandem reactions comprising reverse water-gas shift, C-C coupling and isomerization. Unique pore structure and appropriate Bronsted acid properties of HMCM-22 effectively suppressed aromatization, while promoting isomerization. Coke deposition inside the micropores of HMCM-22 causes the decline of isoparaffin yield without changing the total yield of heavy hydrocarbons. Both the physicochem. properties and catalytic performances of the catalysts could still keep their original levels after several reaction-regeneration cycles, indicating a promising potential application in the future commercialization process of CO2 hydrogenation. The Fischer-Tropsch synthesis of lower olefins (FTO) is an alternative process for the prodn. of major chem. building blocks from natural gas, coal, or biomass-derived synthesis gas. The addn. of low concns. of sulfur plus sodium to Fe/α-Al2O3 resulted in catalysts with high C2-C4 olefins selectivity (∼50%C), enhanced catalytic activity, and decreased methane prodn. (<20%C) when the reaction was carried out at 340°, 20 bar and H2/CO = 1. Sodium reduced methane selectivity by increasing the chain growth probability while sulfur probably reduced the hydrogen coverage of the catalyst resulting in even lower methane selectivities and higher olefin content of the products. The addn. of extra sodium resulted in a detrimental effect on catalytic activity while favoring the formation of carbon deposits. Our results show that the nature and concn. of the promoters play a key role in the design of FTO catalysts with optimum catalytic performance.

Lower olefins are key building blocks for the manuf. of plastics, cosmetics, and drugs. Traditionally, olefins with two to four carbons are produced by steam cracking of crude oil-derived naphtha, but there is a pressing need for alternative feedstocks and processes in view of supply limitations and of environmental issues. Although the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis has long offered a means to convert coal, biomass, and natural gas into hydrocarbon derivs. through the intermediacy of synthesis gas (a mixt. of mol. hydrogen and carbon monoxide), selectivity toward lower olefins tends to be low. We report on the conversion of synthesis gas to C2-4 olefins with selectivity up to 60 wt.%, using catalysts that constitute iron nanoparticles (promoted by sulfur plus sodium) homogeneously dispersed on weakly interactive α-alumina or carbon nanofiber supports.

Paradigm of climate change mitigation technologies is shifting from carbon capture and storage (CCS) to carbon capture and utilization (CCU). Here we propose a new path to CCU - direct CO2 conversion to liq. transportation fuels by reacting with renewable hydrogen produced by solar water splitting. The highly promising and CO2-neutral CCU system is possible by our discovery of a new catalyst that produces liq. hydrocarbon (C5+) selectivity of ∼65% and greatly suppressed CH4 formation to 2-3%, which represents an unprecedented selectivity pattern for direct catalytic CO2 hydrogenation and is very similar to that of conventional CO-based Fischer-Tropsch (FT) synthesis. The catalyst was prepd. by redn. of delafossite-CuFeO2 and in-situ carburization to Hagg carbide (χ-Fe5C2), the active phase for heavy hydrocarbon formation. The ref. catalysts derived from bare Fe2O3, CuO-Fe2O3 mixt., and spinel CuFe2O4 are much less active and produce mainly light hydrocarbons, highlighting the crit. role of delafossite-CuFeO2 as the catalyst precursor. The new catalyst breaks through the limitation of CO2-based FT synthesis and will open the avenue for new opportunity for carbon recycling into valuable liq. fuels at the similar conditions to industrially practiced CO-FT synthesis.

The direct prodn. of light α-olefins (C2=-C4=) from CO2 is of great importance as this process can convert the greenhouse gas into the desired chems. In this study, the crucial roles of Na and Mn promoter in CO2 hydrogenation to produce light α-olefins via the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) over Fe3O4-based catalysts are investigated. The results indicate that both Na and Mn promoter can enhance the reducibility of Fe3O4. In situ XPS and DFT calcns. show that Na facilitates the redn. by electron donation from Na to Fe as the oxygen vacancy formation energy is reduced by Na. In contrast, Mn promotes the redn. by the presence of oxygen vacancy in MnO as the oxygen in Fe oxide can spillover to the vacancy in MnO spontaneously. For un-promoted Fe3O4 catalysts, CO2 hydrogenation dominantly produces light n-paraffins. The addn. of Na remarkably shifts the selectivity to light α-olefins with a sharp decline in the selectivity to light n-paraffins, which is attributed to the electron donation from Na to Fe resulting in the promoted CO dissocn. and the favorable β-H abstraction of surface short alkyl-metal intermediates. The addn. of Mn into Na-contg. Fe3O4 catalysts can obviously further enhance the selectivity to light α-olefins as the spatial hindrance of Mn suppresses the chain growth to increase the amt. of surface short alkyl-metal intermediates.

A high surface area K-promoted iron-based catalyst is prepd. by thermal decompn. of ammonium glycolate complexes, followed by impregnation with an aq. soln. of potassium carbonate, drying and calcination. The duration of the calcination has a dramatic effect on the textural and structural properties of the obtained material, and on the iron oxidn. state. Fast calcinations allow to synthesize materials isostructural with Fe3O4/γ-Fe2O3 that, after a carburization treatment with CO/H2 mixts., are highly active in the CO2 hydrogenation to lower (C2-C4) olefins at mild process conditions (300 °C and 5 barg). Interestingly, the decrease of the operating pressure leads to a shift from the "hydrocarbon synthesis" regime to reverse water gas shift regime. The selectivity to lower olefins is instead maximized at mild process conditions due to the moderate chain growth probability and the slow rate of olefin secondary hydrogenations, which dominate at higher pressure and temps., resp. The former process is activated by type II catalytic sites (iron carbides), while the latter occurs on type III catalytic sites (Fe0). Type I catalytic sites also exist (Fe3O4) and are responsible for the RWGS activity of the catalyst. Collected data suggest that CO is the primary product of CO2 hydrogenation, while hydrocarbons are formed via CO hydrogenation, following a Fischer-Tropsch type mechanism. Eventually, the performances of the prepd. catalyst are compared with those of K-promoted ref. model samples based on com. α-Fe2O3 and Fe3O4 powders. It is found that, due to a better carburization and the higher surface area, the catalyst prepd. by fast decompn. of ammonium glycolate complexes is more active than the ref. materials in terms of both CO2 conversion and C2-C4 olefins selectivity.

The effect of alkali promoter (K, Rb and Cs) on the performance of pptd. iron-based catalysts was investigated for carbon dioxide (CO2) hydrogenation. Characterization by temp.-programmed redn. with CO, Mossbauer spectroscopy, and transmission electron microscopy were used to study the effect of alkali promoter interactions on the carburization and phase transformation behavior of the catalysts. Under similar reaction conditions, cesium (Cs) and rubidium (Rb) promoted catalysts exhibited the highest initial CO2 conversions to higher hydrocarbons. CO2 conversions then decreased to reach steady state conversions around 170 h on stream. At steady state conversion, all three catalysts exhibited similar CO2 conversions and selectivities. For comparison, a lower loaded Cs (1.5 Cs) promoted iron-based catalyst was prepd. It exhibited slightly lower initial conversion than the higher loaded Cs catalyst, but remained very stable. Among all the catalysts at steady state conversion, the 1.5 Cs promoted catalyst exhibited the highest stability. Results indicate a synergistic effect brought on by these promoters that, if balanced, could potentially yield superior CO2 hydrogenation catalysts.

This work investigates the effects of potassium addn. on light olefin prodn. from CO2 hydrogenation over Al2O3-supported Fe-Co bimetallic catalysts. The addn. of small amts. of K to the Fe-Co catalyst significantly enhanced C2-C4 olefin formation. The C2-C4 olefins predominated among C+2 hydrocarbons at a K/Fe at. ratio of 1. Temp.-programmed desorption expts. demonstrated that K addn. diminished the weakly adsorbed hydrogen but enhanced CO2 adsorption on the catalyst surface, which led to significantly enhanced prodn. of light olefins. For C2-C4 olefin synthesis at 573K and 1.0 MPa, the K-promoted Fe-Co/Al2O3 catalyst also showed better performance than the K-promoted Fe-Mn/Al2O3, which is known as a good catalyst for olefin prodn., under the present conditions employed. The pathway of olefin formation from CO2 hydrogenation was analyzed. Light olefins were formed via two-step reactions over K-promoted Fe-Co catalysts with the formation of CO or CO-like intermediates as the first step. Some of these olefins could be further hydrogenated to paraffins, depending on the type and concn. of chemisorbed hydrogen on the catalyst surface.

The effect of potassium was tested with unpromoted and K-promoted Fe-Al-O oxide and Fe5C2 carbide materials, formed during CO2 hydrogenation from Fe-Al-O spinel. Each one of the tested catalysts contained a single phase (oxide or carbide). The 2 wt% potassium enhanced the reverse water gas shift reaction rate of reaction on the oxide phase tenfold compared with the unpromoted oxide. This correlated with increase of Fe2+/Fe3+ ratio (XPS) detg. oxygen vacancies as active sites for reverse water gas shift reaction. Potassium suppressed the methanation rate on the carbide catalyst by a factor of five and increased the CO FTS rate to C2+ hydrocarbons by a factor of 1.4. The EFTEM images and elemental profiles of unpromoted carbide nanocrystals measured after testing in CO hydrogenation displayed an amorphous surface layer enriched with oxygen. Potassium stabilized the surface iron atoms in reduced form. The obsd. effects of potassium on carbide phase were explained by a model implementing carbon vacancies for methanation and near-metallic iron atoms for FTS.

Fe-Co/K-Al2O3 catalyst has been reported to be active and selective for olefin prodn. from CO2 hydrogenation. However, the effect of calcination temp. on the physicochem. properties of Fe-Co/K-Al2O3 catalysts as well as their catalytic activity in CO2 hydrogenation to olefins has not yet been addressed. Here, we show that the calcination temp. (400-800 °C) has significant impacts on metal oxides crystallite size, on the interaction between Fe2O3 and other metal oxides and on the transformation of potassium phases, which affect CO2 conversion, product selectivity as well as yield of olefins. The Fe-Co/K-Al2O3 catalyst calcined at 400 °C achieves the highest CO2 conversion, hydrocarbons selectivity and olefins yield of 49.0%, 90.6% and 18.1%, resp. The CO2 conversion and hydrocarbons selectivity decrease with ascending calcination temp. which is ascribed to the increase of metal oxides crystallite size, inducing stronger interactions between Fe2O3 and other metal oxides. Unlike the CO2 conversion and hydrocarbons selectivity, the olefins to paraffins (O/P) ratio followed a volcano-shaped trend as the function of calcination temp. with a max. at 7.6 over the Fe-Co/K-Al2O3 catalyst calcined at 700 °C. This volcanic trend is attributed to the interplay among the pos. effect of high calcination temp. on the complete decompn. of KNO3 to K2O, a stronger interaction between Fe2O3 and K2O and the formation of KAlO2 phase, favorably suppressing the hydrogenation of olefins, and the neg. effect of high calcination temp. on the increase of the particle size of the active phase and lower dispersion of mixed metal oxides due to a drastic decrease in BET surface area.

Polymetallic fibers of 13Fe2Co/ZrO2 and 13Fe2Co100Zr were prepd. by impregnation and an in situ electrospinning technique. The iron, cobalt and zirconium components in the 13Fe2Co100Zr catalyst are more dispersed than the impregnation one, as indicated by SEM/EDS, TEM, XRD, H2-TPR and N2 adsorption techniques. CO2 conversion increased by a factor of 2 and the selectivity to C+2 hydrocarbons increased 15 times on the 13Fe2Co100Zr polymetallic fibers compared with the 13Fe2Co/ZrO2 supported catalyst. Potassium addn. to the 13Fe2Co100Zr catalyst further improved the selectivity to C=2-C=4, which increased to 27.5% on a 10K13Fe2Co100Zr catalyst. The polymetallic fibers showed stable activity over the reaction period. The activity of the 13Fe2Co/ZrO2 catalyst, however, decreased rapidly due to metal sintering as obsd. with TEM and XRD. The in situ electrospinning technique can effectively prevent metal sintering and provide high CO2 conversion efficiency.

A review. In recent heterogeneous catalysis, much effort has been made in understanding how the size, shape, and compn. of nanoparticles and oxide-metal interfaces affect catalytic performance at the mol. level. Recent advances in colloidal synthetic techniques enable prepg. diverse metallic or bimetallic nanoparticles with well-defined size, shape, and compn. and porous oxides as a high surface support. As nanoparticles become smaller, new chem., phys., and catalytic properties emerge. Geometrically, the smaller the nanoparticle, the greater the relative no. of edge and corner sites per unit surface of the nanoparticle. When the nanoparticles are smaller than a crit. size (2.7 nm), finite-size effects such as a change of adsorption strength or oxidn. state are revealed by changes in their electronic structures. By alloying two metals, the formation of heteroatom bonds and geometric effects such as strain due to the change of metal-metal bond lengths cause new electronic structures to appear in bimetallic nanoparticles. Ceaseless catalytic reaction studies have discovered that the highest reaction yields, product selectivity, and process stability were achieved by detg. the crit. size, shape, and compn. of nanoparticles and by choosing the appropriate oxide support. Depending on the pore size, various kinds of micro-, meso-, and macro-porous materials are fabricated by the aid of structure-directing agents or hard templates. Recent achievements for the prepn. of versatile core/shell nanostructures composing mesoporous oxides, zeolites, and metal org. frameworks provide new insights toward nanocatalysis with novel ideas.
